MED-0769.courseTitle: Integrated Basic, Community Health and Clinical Sciences
MED-0769.UL: not applicable to the M.D. program for students admitted Fall 2013 or later

MED-0787.courseDescription: has students apply knowledge of reversible or modifiable health problems to chronic conditions for diagnosis and management of the patient.

MED-0780.courseDescription: has students build on their knowledge of the normal structure and function of the body and analyze disruptions in health by exploring the pathophysiology of illnesses, their risk factors and risk prevention strategies.
MED-0780.courseTitle: The Patient: Acute or Episodic Health Problems

MED-0781.courseDescription: has students develop clinical reasoning skills used in patient-centered care using focused interviewing, examination, and communication skills.

MED-0782.courseDescription: has students apply concepts that encompass the non-medical expert CanMEDS roles of scholar, communicator, collaborator, advocate, manager and professional in the context of the patient’s change in health status management and prevention.

MED-0783.courseDescription: places students in physicians’ practices for two weeks to further experience interactions among patients, their family physician and the health care system when presenting with a change in health status.

MED-0788.courseDescription: has students advance their assessment skills of patients who have chronic health issues. They will develop verbal and written communication skills required for patient-centered care.

MED-0789.courseDescription: continues to develop student competencies in the non-Medical Expert CanMEDS roles introduced in previous special project courses.

MED-0773.courseDescription: introduces students to the structure and function of healthy people in all age groups in an integrated way. Students will learn in the context of a person as part of a family in a community. Students will begin to examine their future roles as professionals in our health care system.

MED-0775.courseDescription: introduces students to concepts that encompass the non-medical expert CanMEDS roles of scholar, communicator, collaborator, advocate, manager and professional in the context of the healthy person, family and the physician within health care systems.

MED-0774.courseDescription: introduces students to the main elements of the medical interview and techniques of interviewing. Students will develop skills in examining healthy individuals within all age ranges. Communication and collaboration skills will be developed in the context of patient-centered care and working with other health care providers.

MED-0776.courseDescription: places students in community sites for two weeks to experience a variety of aspects of the health care system with various health agencies, a family physician, and other health care providers.

MED-0797.courseDescription: enables students to be assigned to a physician, physician group or discipline for experiences that focus on following patients as they interact with the health care system.

MED-0796.courseDescription: are offered in two - four week blocks in approved areas of study for a maximum of twelve weeks.

MED-0795.courseDescription: provides students with opportunities to advance their procedural and clinical skills to promote patient safety and work effectively in team settings.

MED-0794.courseDescription: immerses students in the clinical environment through experiences in core disciplines including internal medicine, surgery, obstetrics and gynecology, rural family practice, paediatrics and psychiatry.

MED-0790.courseDescription: introduces students to skills required to succeed in their clinical experiences to achieve a level of competency for Phase 4.

MED-0798.courseDescription: will focus on the transition to postgraduate training as a part of the continuum of medical education.
